messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 64 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: How Real is Incomputability in Physics?

Paper Abstract: Abstract A physical system is determined by a finite set of initial conditions and laws represented by equations. The system is computable if we can solve the equations in all instances using a ‚Äúfinite body of mathematical knowledge". In this case, if the laws of the system can be coded into a computer program, then given the system‚Äôs initial conditions of the system, one can compute the system‚Äôs evolution. This scenario is tacitly taken for granted. But is this reasonable? The answer is negative, and a straightforward example is when the initial conditions or equations use irrational numbers, like Chaitin‚Äôs Omega Number: no program can deal with such numbers because of their ‚Äúinfinity‚Äù. Are there incomputable physical systems? This question has been theoretically studied in the last 30‚Äì40 years. This article presents a class of quantum protocols producing quantum random bits. Theoretically, we prove that every infinite sequence generated by these quantum protocols is strongly incomputable ‚Äì no algorithm computing any bit of such a sequence can be proved correct. This theoretical result is not only more robust than the ones in the literature: experimental results support and complement it.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 64 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 64"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Strong Kochen-Specker theorem and incomputability of quantum randomness",
        "Experimentally probing the algorithmic randomness and incomputability of quantum randomness",
        "Value-indefinite observables are almost everywhere",
        "A quantum random number generator certified by value indefiniteness",
        "A non-probabilistic model of relativised predictability in physics",
        "Primes is in P",
        "A new quantum random number generator certified by value indefiniteness",
        "Undecidability of the spectral gap in one dimension",
        "From bi-immunity to absolute undecidability",
        "A physicist‚Äôs second reaction to Mengenlehre",
        "Information and Randomness‚ÄîAn Algorithmic Perspective",
        "Experimental evidence of quantum randomness incomputability",
        "Quantum randomness and value indefiniteness",
        "A note on Monte Carlo primality tests and algorithmic information theory",
        "The construction of decimals normal in the scale of ten",
        "Optimal design for universal multiport interferometers",
        "Incomputability in nature",
        "Introduction to Algorithms",
        "Incomputability at the foundations of physics (A study in the philosophy of science)",
        "Undecidability of the spectral gap",
        "Undecidability and incompleteness in classical mechanics",
        "The solution of the n-body problem",
        "Physics and reality",
        "Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?",
        "Das Kausalgesetz und seine Grenzen",
        "The Law of Causality and its Limits (Vienna Circle Collection)",
        "Indeterminism in physics and intuitionistic mathematics",
        "The principles of mechanics presented in a new form",
        "Undecidability principle and the uncertainty principle even for classical systems",
        "Searching for evidence of algorithmic randomness and incomputability in the output of quantum random number generators",
        "Charge-insensitive qubit design derived from the cooper pair box",
        "The problem of hidden variables in quantum mechanics",
        "A notion of mechanistic theory",
        "Realization of a quantum random generator certified with the Kochen-Specker theorem",
        "Uncomputability and physical law",
        "La theorie de l‚Äôobservation en m√©canique quantique; No. 775 of Actualit√©s scientifiques et industrielles: Expos√©s de physique g√©n√©rale, publi√©s sous la direction de Paul Langevin",
        "The theory of observation in quantum mechanics",
        "Incomputability in physics",
        "Fast and unconditional all-microwave reset of a superconducting qubit",
        "Riemann‚Äôs hypothesis and tests for primality",
        "Unpredictability and undecidability in dynamical systems",
        "Neural networks for on-the-fly single-shot state classification",
        "Wissenschaft und Hypothese",
        "Computability in Analysis and Physics",
        "Probabilistic algorithm for testing primality",
        "Experimental realization of any discrete unitary operator",
        "Prime Numbers and Computer Methods for Factorization, chapter Classical Methods of Factorization, pages 141‚Äì172",
        "A fast Monte-Carlo test for primality",
        "Erratum: A fast Monte-Carlo test for primality",
        "On random r.e. sets",
        "Encyclopedia of Cryptography and Security, chapter Probabilistic Primality Test, pages 980‚Äì980",
        "Memoire sur le probl√®me de trois corps",
        "The transcendental character of determinism",
        "The quantum coin toss ‚Äì testing microphysical undecidability",
        "Randomness & Undecidability in Physics",
        "Omega and the time evolution of the n-body problem",
        "Physical (A)Causality, volume 192 of Fundamental Theories of Physics",
        "The global solution of the nùëõn-body problem",
        "Power series solutions and integral manifold of the n-body problem",
        "Mittheilung, einen von K√∂nig Oscar II gestifteten mathematischen Preis betreffend. Communication sur un prix de math√©matiques fond√© par le roi Oscar II",
        "Undecidability and intractability in theoretical physics",
        "SU(2) and SU(1,1) interferometers",
        "A foundational principle for quantum mechanics",
        "Computable Universe: Understanding and Exploring Nature as Computation"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 64 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in How Real is Incomputability in Physics?, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
